text: Hey there Head Squeezers hope you're well.

This one has come in from Tim McCabe who asks,
why do jellyfish sting?

Now I think it was one of the greatest minds
of this if not any generation Mr Karl Pilkington
who said 'Jellyfish....Do we need 'em?'

Well Karl yes we do because they are part
of the food chain, but I can't deny they are
a bit of an odd beast.

They're not even a fish they're a plankton
made of 98% water.

They have no bones, no heart and technically
no brain but they've been around for 650 million

years and there are thousands of different
species so clearly they're doing something
right.

So Tim, the sting, they use it to capture
prey and as a defence mechanism.

A jellyfish's tentacles are covered in cells
called nematocysts and in those contain stinging
threads.

If it comes up against a foreign body like
a human on the beach it will unfurl the stinging

threads and shoot out, shoot out neurotoxin
venom.

In the case of its prey it will paralyse it
in the case of us it just hurts.

Tell me in the comments below if you've experienced
that kind of pain before.
So how do you treat for a jellyfish sting?
Yes the urine issue.
Had to come up at some point didn't it?
So, does it actually work?

This idea that if you pee on someone's limb
that's been stung by jellyfish, will that
help?
A recent study suggests no.

It actually reckons it could make the sting
burn more.
Ahh.

The thing is a sting tends to be alkaline
so in order to neutralise it you need acid

so vinegar would be a great thing to pour
over your sting.

So whoever came up with that idea that you
need to take a leak on someone if they've
been stung by jellyfish?

I don't know, I couldn't find out, but I salute
that person one of the best practical jokers
in history.
Until next time happy Head Squeezing.
